author: Rádio e Televisão de Portugal
title: Pelo menos 14 feridos em novo ataque noturno russo em Kharkiv
text:
Pelo menos 14 feridos em novo ataque noturno russo em Kharkiv
Pelo menos 14 civis ficaram hoje feridos num ataque noturno da Rússia com `drones` à cidade de Kharkiv, no nordeste da Ucrânia, um dia depois de três pessoas terem morrido e outras 60 terem ficado feridas.
"Durante a noite, o inimigo atacou Kharkiv com `drones`. Incêndios ocorreram nos distritos de Saltivskiy, Slobodskiy e Shevchenkivskiy. Casas, estabelecimentos comerciais e carros foram queimados e 14 pessoas ficaram feridas, incluindo quatro crianças", informaram os serviços de emergência estaduais na rede social Telegram.
Na noite de terça para quarta-feira, os ataques com `drones` mataram três pessoas: uma mulher de 47 anos e dois homens de 65 anos, e outras 60 pessoas ficaram feridas, incluindo um menino de cinco anos.
Nos últimos dias, a Rússia intensificou os ataques com `drones`, tendo lançado um número recorde de 479 destes aparelhos não tripulados contra a Ucrânia no domingo à noite.
A Rússia tem atacado diariamente a Ucrânia desde que invadiu em grande escala o país vizinho, em 24 de fevereiro de 2022, bombardeando cidades e aldeias.
O conflito já causou a morte de dezenas de milhares de pessoas, tanto civis como militares.
Há vários meses que Kiev pede a Moscovo uma trégua de 30 dias para iniciar conversações de paz.
A Rússia tem recusado a trégua até agora, argumentando que a pausa nos combates daria tempo ao exército ucraniano, em dificuldades, para se rearmar.

author: Juan Manuel Delgado
title: Piracy Shield salva su último escollo: ver el fútbol gratis por IPTV será casi imposible | Computer Hoy
text: Las listas IPTV pirata han estado en la web durante muchos años, pero es ahora cuando realmente han comenzado a ganar gran relevancia y captar mucha atención. Estos servicios se han convertido en el objetivo principal de la policía, que buscan cerrarlos a toda costa debido a su transmisión ilegal. Es importante destacar que estas plataformas se han convertido en un auténtico quebradero de cabeza para los propietarios de los derechos de fútbol , así como de las series y películas, ya que permiten el acceso gratuito o a un precio muy reducido a este contenido. En última instancia, esto implica una pérdida de ingresos para los propietarios, quienes suelen ser los canales de televisión tradicionales, las productoras de cine y, por supuesto, las ligas de fútbol . Frente a esta situación, las autoridades han declarado una auténtica guerra contra las listas IPTV pirata , tomando como inspiración la reciente ley italiana, Piracy Shield , un sistema revolucionario destinado a erradicar estos servicios ilegales. Esta ley fue presentada en Italia hace apenas unos meses, y desde su divulgación ha generado multitud de críticas. Esto se debe a que obliga a las operadoras a tomar medidas en un plazo de 30 minutos desde la presentación de la demanda interpuesta por los propietarios de los derechos , y a actuar sin necesidad de autorización judicial. Frente a esta situación, las operadoras presentaron una demanda judicial con el objetivo de posponer la implementación de Piracy Shield . La asociación italiana de operadoras, Assoprovider , argumentó que bloquear sitios web conllevaría un coste excesivamente alto. Llegando incluso a poner en riesgo la supervivencia de muchas empresas en Italia debido a los elevados gastos asociados con la ejecución de este procedimiento. Además, muchas páginas web inocentes que comparten servidor con servicios pirata se verían afectados. Sin embargo, tras una intensa disputa legal, el tribunal administrativo de Lazio, Italia, ha desestimado la demanda para poner fin al nuevo sistema de bloqueo de IPTV en el país y ha frustrado las aspiraciones de Assoprovider de frenar esta legislación. De esta manera, el tribunal respalda el Piracy Shield , considerándolo de interés público para la protección de los derechos de autor . Además, los juzgados desestiman las preocupaciones sobre posibles errores en el rápido bloqueo de servidores de las listas IPTV y argumentan que el límite de 30 minutos es necesario para abordar de manera ágil la piratería, especialmente en eventos deportivos de corta duración. Sin lugar a dudas, este representa un gran avance hacia el cierre definitivo de las IPTV piratas , propinando un golpe contundente a todos los involucrados en ofrecer estos servicios. En consecuencia, acceder al fútbol a través de esta vía se tornará prácticamente imposible . Es relevante destacar que esta legislación ha suscitado mucho interés en España y la Unión Europea, donde se han imitado las acciones con cierres masivos y numerosas detenciones, por lo que el futuro de estas plataformas luce prácticamente oscuro.

author: PA News Agency
title: Running clubs to be recommended to long-term sick under Government plans | Echo
text: Running and gardening clubs will be recommended to those on long-term sickness leave in a bid to get people back to work. Doctors, employers, job centres, social workers and charities will be encouraged to suggest therapy and life coaching under new Government plans to create a national occupational health service and reduce the number of people whom GPs sign off from work. Community activities such as singing, cooking or gardening clubs will also be offered through NHS “social prescribing” initiatives. Work and Pensions Secretary Mel Stride and Health Secretary Victoria Atkins said the scheme is not a “one size fits all” but they hope it will work with other services to help people stay in employment. They told The Times: “We know the longer someone spends out of work, the harder it becomes for them to find a job. They added: “We also know that one in five of those claiming the highest level of health benefits want to work and feel they could do so with the right support.” Currently, there are 2.2 million people claiming Universal Credit with no work requirements. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has previously committed to tackling the growing numbers of those too ill to work. The pilots will see 15 areas test a service known as WorkWell which involves work coaches, physiotherapy and mental health treatment. Following the trials, the Governments hopes to expand the scheme nationally but key elements of it will not take effect until 2025. Ms Atkins and Mr Stride said: “Where someone could fall out of work and on to long-term sickness benefits, WorkWell is designed to swoop in and provide the support that people need to stay in work, or return as soon as possible.” Labour’s shadow employment minister Alison McGovern told The Times the scheme is “all too little and it’s far too late”. author: Rafia Tasleem
title: Thenmala: Harmonizing Eco-Tourism and Conservation in India's Western Ghats
text:
In the heart of south India, nestled at the foothills of the Western Ghats in Kerala's Kollam district, lies a verdant paradise that has emerged as a beacon of sustainable travel. Thenmala, India's first planned eco-tourist destination, not only boasts a UNESCO World Heritage Site but is also a sanctuary for thousands of endangered species of flora and fauna. This unique confluence of conservation and tourism offers a window into the rich biodiversity of the region, emphasizing the balance between human enjoyment and environmental preservation.
A Journey Through Thenmala's Diverse Zones
Thenmala's careful planning is evident in its division into three primary zones - Culture, Leisure, and Adventure - each offering visitors a distinct experience while subtly educating them on the importance of ecological balance. The Culture Zone serves as a gateway to the region's rich heritage, showcasing traditional Keralite architecture, art forms, and cuisine. Here, one can start their day with a tranquil walk through the sculpture garden, where local myths and legends are brought to life through stone and metal. Moving on, the Leisure Zone promises a serene escape into nature's lap, with its butterfly safaris, musical fountains, and the ever-popular boating on the Shendurney River. However, for those seeking a thrill, the Adventure Zone does not disappoint. From mountain biking along rugged terrains to trekking through dense forests, it offers a rush of adrenaline coupled with a touch of wilderness.
Conservation at Its Core: Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary and Beyond
At the core of Thenmala's eco-tourism model lies the Shendurney Wildlife Sanctuary, a haven for wildlife enthusiasts and researchers. This sanctuary is home to an expansive variety of endemic species, including several that are considered endangered. It plays a crucial role in Thenmala's ecosystem, offering a safe haven for these species while allowing humans to marvel at their beauty and understand their significance in our world. Adjacent to the sanctuary, the Tropical Treehouse provides a unique overnight experience for visitors, offering panoramic views of the untouched forest canopy. Meanwhile, the Deer Rehabilitation Center stands as a testament to Thenmala's commitment to animal welfare, rehabilitating and releasing deer back into the wild.
Addressing the Elephant in the Room: Eco-Tourism's Impact
Despite its many attractions and conservation efforts, Thenmala faces challenges common to popular eco-tourist destinations worldwide. The influx of tourists, while beneficial for the local economy, raises concerns about the potential negative impacts on the environment. Issues such as littering, habitat disturbance, and increased pressure on natural resources are prevalent. Furthermore, the rates for visiting Thenmala have sparked a debate on the accessibility of eco-tourism, questioning whether it should be a privilege only for those who can afford it. These concerns highlight the delicate balance between promoting tourism for economic development and ensuring the preservation of natural habitats.
In conclusion, Thenmala stands as a shining example of how eco-tourism, when planned and executed with care, can serve as a powerful tool for conservation while offering unforgettable experiences to its visitors. It showcases the rich and diverse ecosystem of the Western Ghats, bringing to light the need for sustainable practices in tourism. As eco-tourism continues to evolve, destinations like Thenmala remind us of the importance of preserving the natural wonders of our world for generations to come, urging us to tread lightly and with respect on this planet we call home.
